problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $f$ be a twice differentiable function on the
  open interval $(-1,1)$ such that $f(0)=1$.
  Suppose $f$ also satisfies $f(x) \ge 0$,
  $f'(x) \le 0$, and $f''(x) \le f(x)$, for all $x\ge 0$.
  Show that $f'(0) \ge -\sqrt2$.
\end{problem*}
solution:
\verbsoln{Manali Chakraborty}

\begin{soln}
  Define $g(x) = e^{-x}(f'(x)+f(x))$
  and $h(x)=e^x(f'(x)-f(x))$. Then note that
  $g'(x)=e^{-x}(f''(x)-f(x))\le 0$ which implies $g$ is
  non-increasing and hence, for all $x\in [0,1)$,
  \[
    g(x) \le g(0) \implies e^{-x}(f'(x)+f(x)) \le f'(0)+1,
  \]
  that is,
  \[
    f'(x)+f(x) \le e^x (f'(0) + 1)
  .\]
  Similarly, note that $h'(x) = e^x(f''(x)-f(x))\le 0$
  which implies $h$ is non-increasing and hence, for all
  $x \in [0,1)$,
  \[
    h(x) \le h(0) \implies e^{x}(f'(x)-f(x)) \le f'(0)-1,
  \]
  that is,
  \[
    f'(x)-f(x) \le e^{-x}(f'(0)+1)
  .\]
  Adding these two conditions, we get
  \[
    2f'(x) \le e^x(f'(0)+1) + e^{-x}(f'(0)-1)
  .\]
  
  As $f$ is twice differentiable, $f'$ is continuous and hence
  integrable. So integrating the preceding inequality on
  the interval $[0,t]$, we get
  \[
    2\int_{0}^{t} f'(x)\mathrm{d}x 
    \le (f'(0)+1)\int_{0}^{t} e^x \mathrm{d}x
    + (f'(0)-1)\int_{0}^{t} e^{-x} \mathrm{d}x
  \]
  which implies
  \[
    2f(t)-2 \le f'(0)(e^{t}-e^{-t}) + e^t + e^{-t}-2
  .\]

  Using the fact that $f(x)\ge 0$ for all $x\in [0,1)$, we get
  \[
    f'(0) \ge -\left(\frac{e^t + e^{-t}}{e^t - e^{-t}}\right)
    = -\left(\frac{e^{2t} + 1}{e^{2t} - 1}\right)
  \]
  for all $t \in [0,1)$. Limiting $t\to 1^-$, we get
  \[
    f'(0) \ge -\left(\frac{e^2+1}{e^2-1}\right) > -\sqrt{2}
  .\qedhere\]
\end{soln}
